propositions.text: The story begins on April 16th, Tuesday, at 3:30 PM, when the narrator, Nonoguchi Shū, departs for Kunihiko Hidaka's residence.
Hidaka's house is located in a beautiful, well-maintained residential area characterized by high-end homes and occasional mansions.
The area was previously a dense thicket, and many homes retain original forest trees in their courtyards.
Beech and gravel trees grow profusely within the walls, casting dense shade over the alleys.
The streets are deliberately designed as one-way, possibly as a status symbol related to safety.
For Nonoguchi, a local youth, buying a house in this area was a dream to be realized.
Hidaka's house, while not a mansion, is spacious enough for a couple.
The main house features a traditional Japanese roof but incorporates Western elements like bay windows, an arched entrance, and window box flower beds on the second floor.
These Western elements are likely a compromise, with the wife having a stronger preference for a European castle-like home, indicated by the brick perimeter wall.
Nonoguchi notes that Hidaka is now his 'ex-wife'.
Upon arriving at the gate, Nonoguchi rings the doorbell but receives no answer.
He checks the parking lot and sees Hidaka's SAAB is missing, suggesting he is out.
Nonoguchi decides to enter the property uninvited, heading towards the courtyard to see a double-flowered cherry tree.
In the courtyard, he encounters an unfamiliar woman bending down and looking at something on the ground.
She is wearing jeans and a sweater and holding a white cloth-like object.
The woman apologizes, explaining her hat blew into the yard and she entered because the residents seemed absent.
She appears to be between 35 and 40 years old, with plain features and a sallow complexion.
Nonoguchi internally questions the strength of the wind, given her explanation.
When Nonoguchi comments on her focus on the ground, she claims to be admiring the lawn's upkeep.
The woman leaves, and shortly after, a car engine is heard in the parking lot.
Hidaka returns with Rie, who apologizes for the delay caused by traffic.
Nonoguchi mentions he went to the yard to see the cherry blossoms.
Hidaka notes the blossoms are starting to fall and mentions the problem of caterpillars from the tree affecting his studio window.
Hidaka expresses relief at leaving the 'caterpillar hell' and offers Nonoguchi coffee.
Inside, the house appears mostly packed, with wall hangings removed.
Hidaka confirms most belongings are packed, with the moving company handling the rest.
They plan to stay at the Crown Hotel, but Hidaka might sleep at home.
In the studio, a 10-tatami room, only a voltage desk and a small bookshelf remain.
Hidaka reveals he has a manuscript deadline for the next day, needing to submit the final installment of a serialized work by midnight.
The manuscript is for 'Sumisei Monthly' and requires thirty more pages.
Rie brings coffee, and they discuss Vancouver's weather, which is colder than Japan.
Nonoguchi expresses the benefit of a cool summer, while Hidaka jokes about the impossibility of working in a cool room.
Hidaka invites Nonoguchi to visit and offers to be his guide in Canada.
Hidaka looks out at the cherry tree, regretting that he will miss its full bloom.
Nonoguchi promises to send photos of the blossoms.
Nonoguchi decides to tell Hidaka about the strange woman he encountered in the yard.
Hidaka's reaction shifts from surprise to understanding upon hearing the description.
He describes the woman as looking like a 'wooden folk doll'.
Hidaka reveals her name is likely Niimi, she lives nearby, appears younger than her age (over 40), has a son in middle school, and her husband works away from home.
He states that the woman hates them, not that they have a good relationship.
The reason for her animosity is a dead cat.
The cat, which died suddenly by the roadside, was suspected to have been poisoned.
The woman suspects Hidaka poisoned the cat, believing it ate poisoned pellets he placed in the yard.
Hidaka shows Nonoguchi an article in 'Sumisei Monthly' titled 'The Limit of Tolerance', which details his frustration with cats.
The article describes issues like cat feces in the yard, paw prints on car hoods, and damaged plants, all attributed to a white and brown cat.
Despite attempts to deter the cats, nothing worked, pushing him to his limit.
Nonoguchi realizes the connection and understands why the woman suspects him.
The woman had confronted Hidaka the previous week, implying he poisoned the cat.
Rie had angrily dismissed her, but the woman's lingering presence suggests she is still searching for evidence of poison.
Nonoguchi comments on her persistence.
Hidaka mentions that Rie informed the woman about their move to Canada, suggesting she only had to endure the cats for a short time.
Nonoguchi points out that they had no reason to kill the cat at this particular time.
Hidaka, with a smile, confesses, "It was me."
He admits to putting the poisoned pellets in the yard and expresses surprise at how smoothly things went.
Nonoguchi initially believes he is joking but notices Hidaka's serious demeanor.
Hidaka explains how to make the poisoned pellets: mixing pesticide with cat food, as cats apparently eat anything.
Nonoguchi feels uneasy asking why Hidaka did it.
Hidaka explains that the house was difficult to rent out due to the cat problem, which would deter potential tenants.
He reasoned that removing the cat deterrents wouldn't solve the issue if potential renters saw cat feces everywhere.
Hidaka believes it's the owner's responsibility to manage their pets.
When asked if Rie knows, Hidaka denies it, stating she would consider him a devil for liking cats so much.
The phone rings, and Hidaka speaks with Mr. Yamabe from 'Sumisei'.
Hidaka assures him the manuscript will be finished tonight and will be sent from the hotel.
Nonoguchi decides to leave, but Rie interrupts to announce the arrival of Ms. Fujio.
Hidaka recognizes the name as Fujio Miyako, implying a significant issue.
He believes she heard about their move to Canada and is coming to discuss something.
Hidaka agrees to meet her, wanting to resolve the issue there.
Nonoguchi asks if Fujio is the sister of Fujio Masaya, whom Hidaka implicitly referenced.
Hidaka confirms she is his sister and expresses concern about her demands, potentially involving the withdrawal or rewriting of his books.
Nonoguchi leaves, offering a silent farewell to Hidaka, who is about to meet Fujio Miyako.
Rie apologizes for the inconvenience, and Nonoguchi reiterates his intention to see them off.
Nonoguchi returns to his small apartment, which serves as both a studio and living space.
Oshima from Dōji Publishing arrives precisely on time, bringing a gift of Japanese sweets.
Nonoguchi offers Oshima tea and his manuscript.
While Oshima reads, the cordless phone rings.
It's Hidaka, sounding troubled, asking if Nonoguchi is busy.
Nonoguchi mentions having a guest but agrees to meet Hidaka at his place at 8 PM.
Oshima prepares to leave, but Nonoguchi assures him he has time and encourages him to continue reading.
Nonoguchi speculates that Hidaka's urgency is related to Fujio Miyako.
He recalls Hidaka's novel 'Forbidden Ground', which thinly disguised the life of a printmaker named Fujio Masaya.
The novel depicted Masaya's past misdeeds and student-era behavior, even including his death at the hands of a prostitute, matching reality.
The novel became a bestseller, leading Fujio Masaya's family to protest.
His mother and sister demanded the book be recalled and rewritten, citing the unauthorized use of Masaya's life and damage to his reputation.
They did not request financial compensation, leaving the possibility of other motives open.
Nonoguchi ponders what he can do to help if negotiations with Fujio Miyako have failed.
Oshima finishes reading and praises Nonoguchi's work for its warmth and nostalgia.
Nonoguchi, relieved by the positive feedback, suggests they discuss future plans over dinner.
They go to a nearby restaurant, where Nonoguchi reveals his meeting with Kunihiko Hidaka.
Oshima expresses surprise and admiration, mentioning Hidaka had initially rejected an invitation from his company but introduced Oshima to them instead.
Nonoguchi explains his childhood friendship with Hidaka and their continued correspondence.
Oshima asks if Nonoguchi would consider writing adult fiction, to which Nonoguchi truthfully replies he would if given the opportunity.
After dinner, Nonoguchi sees Oshima off at the station.
Arriving at Hidaka's house at 8 PM, Nonoguchi finds it completely dark and the doorbell unresponsive.
He suspects he might have misunderstood the meeting time or location.
He goes to a nearby park and calls the Crown Hotel from a phone booth.
Rie answers, stating Hidaka is not there and is likely still at home working.
Nonoguchi informs Rie that the house appears empty, which confuses her.
Rie decides to go to the house and estimates arriving in about 40 minutes.
Nonoguchi checks Hidaka's house again before going to a coffee shop.
At the coffee shop, the owner inquires about Hidaka's absence.
After spending time at the coffee shop, Nonoguchi returns to Hidaka's house.
He sees Rie arriving by taxi, her expression turning to worry upon seeing the dark house.
Rie unlocks the door, and they enter the cold, seemingly empty house.
The studio door is locked, which is unusual for Hidaka.
Upon unlocking the studio, they find the computer screen emitting light, indicating it's on.
Hidaka is found dead on the floor, facing them.
Nonoguchi confirms Hidaka is dead.
Rie collapses in grief.
A police forensics team arrives at the scene while Nonoguchi and Rie wait in the living room.
Inspector Matsuda, the lead investigator, questions Nonoguchi and Rie about the events leading up to the discovery of the body.
Nonoguchi recounts receiving a call from Hidaka around 6 PM, who only mentioned needing to discuss something.
He states that Hidaka did not mention Fujio Miyako at that time.
Rie confirms Fujio Miyako left around 5 PM.
She mentions that Hidaka seemed troubled after his discussion with Fujio Miyako but told her not to worry.
The inspector reviews the information about their planned trip to Canada and Hidaka staying behind to work.
He asks about others who knew about their travel plans, mentioning the 'Sumisei' employees.
Rie states she has no recollection of suspicious individuals near their home.
Nonoguchi hesitates to mention the woman he saw in the yard, deeming her motive for murder too extreme.
Inspector Matsuda arranges for Nonoguchi to be taken home by a police car.
Outside, Nonoguchi encounters Kaga, a former teacher of his who is now a police detective.
Kaga reveals he recognized Nonoguchi's name from the case file.
They discuss Nonoguchi's past as a teacher and his current career as a children's book author, which led to his acquaintance with Hidaka.
Nonoguchi explains Hidaka's literary career and recommends a book titled 'Hotaru' (Firefly) for Kaga to read.
They discuss Hidaka's reasons for moving to Canada and his recent marriage to Rie.
Nonoguchi reflects on his regret for not arriving earlier to see Hidaka.
Kaga asks if Hidaka was involved in any other disputes, related to his novels or personal life.
Kaga inquires about specific names: Nishizaki Namiko, Kozano Tetsuji, and Aizunabe Hajime.
Nonoguchi recognizes these as characters from Hidaka's current serialized novel, 'Hyō no Tobira' (The Door of Ice).
They discuss the fact that Hidaka was still working on this novel at the time of his death.
Nonoguchi states that Hidaka needed to write thirty pages that night.
Kaga suggests the number of pages written could help estimate the time of death.
Nonoguchi estimates Hidaka's writing speed at four pages per hour, or six pages when rushed.
Kaga reveals the police estimate the time of death to be between 5 PM and 7 PM, pending autopsy results.
Nonoguchi asks how Hidaka was killed.
Kaga explains Hidaka was strangled with a telephone cord and also suffered a blow to the back of the head with a brass paperweight.
The police suspect someone knocked him out from behind before strangling him.
Kaga asks Nonoguchi for the magazine serializing Hidaka's novel.
Nonoguchi returns home, feeling overwhelmed and decides to document his experience in writing.
Hidaka's death is reported in the morning papers, with extensive media coverage.
The newspaper reports largely align with the facts, though Nonoguchi's role as a co-discoverer is omitted.
The police are investigating both impulsive and premeditated murder, inferring the perpetrator entered through the studio window due to the locked main door.
A TV reporter contacts Nonoguchi, having learned of his involvement.
Nonoguchi deflects questions, referring them to the police.
Another reporter arrives, persisting in their interview attempts.
Nonoguchi relents, allowing himself to be interviewed, which consumes his morning.
During a TV interview, Nonoguchi describes Hidaka as a strong-willed individual with both kind and surprisingly cold aspects.

hierarchy.structure: The document is divided into three chapters: 'Event Chapter: Nonoguchi Shū's Notes-1', 'Event Chapter: Nonoguchi Shū's Notes-2', and 'Chapter Two'. It follows a chronological narrative of the events leading up to and immediately following the murder of Kunihiko Hidaka, interspersed with Nonoguchi's reflections and interviews with the police.
